Thanks, Kent. Using @BeforeClass and @After annotations actually solve
my problem: both how to use resource more wisely (calling once to do the
setup for all the tests) and keeping track of index variable throughout
all the tests in the class. I knew that it would be some simple options
in JUnit that I have overlooked while reading the cookbook... 

 

Thanks again everyone for your expertise,

Vietchau

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Kent Beck
Sent: Friday, December 22, 2006 1:40 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] How JUnit runs test class

 

Dear Vietchau,

When I first started writing automated tests, I would come in and see a
stack of test failures on my chair from the nightly run. The first few
times
I get excited, but then I realized that that there were always one or
two
real failures and that the remaining failures resulted from those.
That's
when I decided that test isolation was a valuable and important
property--the success or failure of one test should not affect the
success
or failure of another. One concrete corollary of this principle is the
JUnit
policy of creating and setting up a new instance for each test. 

I wrote a little JUnit-ish performance testing framework while I was
writing
Implementation Patterns. Since some of the operations I was measuring
were
very short, I didn't want an object allocation in the inner loop of the
timer so I reused the instances. I found it difficult to return each
instance to exactly the same state after the timed operation as it was
in
before.

Separate instances don't guarantee test isolation. If you use global or
external resources, they can carry state between tests. However, the
separate instances give you a better chance of writing isolated tests.
This
is a case where I am happy to spend some CPU cycles to simplify the
programming tasks. If you are willing to do the work yourself to return
the
world to its original state at the end of every test or you are willing
to
give up test isolation, you can use one of the mechanisms for shared
setup--TestSetup in JUnit 3.8.x and @BeforeClass in JUnit 4.

Regards,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

Subject: [junit] How JUnit runs test class

Dear all,

I am new to JUnit and so my question may be obvious... Is there a way to
run all test methods in a test class by create only one instance of the
class in JUnit? That is, not creating a new instance of the class for
each test? 

I use 

org.junit.runner.JUnitCore.run(myClass.class)

in the main program

and if myClass has 100 test methods, the program will create 100
instances of myClass.

I find that wasteful of resource because each time it will have to do
all the setup again.

Thanks,

Vietchau
